Graphical abstract Thickness manipulation on non-layered 2D carbon complexes is achieved through a “tailored gel expanding” strategy. The optimized size and CNTs branches endow the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC with excellent lithium storage properties. Non-layered two-dimensional (2D) carbon complexes manifest great potential in energy-related applications owing to their exotic electronic structures, large electrochemically active surface, and intriguing synergistic effects. However, reliable method for mass production and thickness manipulation of 2D carbon complexes remains great challenges. Here, inspired by blowing chewing gum into bubbles, a “tailored gel expanding” strategy is proposed for high-yield synthesis of non-layered 2D carbon complexes with tailored thickness from ~12 nm to ~1 μm, by controllable pyrolysis of metal-polymeric gel with adequate crosslinking degree. The key feature for thickness manipulation is introducing NH4NO3 in sol–gel process, which tailors the expansion behavior of gel precursor during subsequent pyrolysis. Various of 2D sheets with intimately coupled N,O-doped carbon (NOC) and NiCo-based (NiCo, (NiCo)S2, (NiCo)Se2, NiCo2O4, (NiCo)(PO3)2) nanocrystals are obtained on a large scale and without any impurities. Moreover, these 2D products are branched with in-situ grown CNTs on the surface, accelerating electrons transfer and preventing the nanosheets from stacking. As a demonstration, the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC with optimized thickness manifests excellent lithium storage properties in both half and full cells. This method paves a new path for massive and controlled production of non-layered 2D materials with tailored thickness and robust structure stability for energy-related applications. Keywords Two-dimensional materials Non-layered structures Thickness manipulation Carbon nanotubes Lithium-ion batteries 1 Introduction Owing to their high specific surface area and exotic electronic properties, two-dimensional (2D) materials have demonstrated great potentials in energy-related applications [1–4]. Generally, 2D materials could be classified into layered and non-layered structures [5,6]. Layered 2D materials with strong in-plane chemical bonds but weak van der Waals interactions between planes, have been intensively investigated because layered nanosheets with tailored thickness could be easily obtained by either exfoliation or chemical vapor deposition (CVD), which demonstrate good electrochemical properties [7–11]. Inspired by layered materials, constructing non-layered materials (e.g., metal, metal oxides, carbon) into 2D structures, has witnessed tremendous interests over the past few years [12–15]. Particularly, non-layered 2D materials are with abundant surface dangling bonds and noticeable structural distortion, endowing them with adjustable band gaps and superior carrier mobility [16]. These intriguing electronic and structural properties promise non-layered nanosheets ideal candidates in energy storage and conversion applications [17–19]. Among these non-layered materials, 2D carbon complexes consisting of carbon nanosheets and active components (e.g., metal, oxides, sulfides, selenides) have received most research attentions, due to their robust mechanical property and intriguing synergistic effects [20–22]. Promoting practical application of 2D carbon complexes requires controllable and simple synthetic method. Currently, one powerful strategy to synthesize non-layered 2D carbon complexes is pyrolysis of inorganic–organic precursors (IOPs), including metal–organic frameworks, metal chelates, and metal-polymer framework [20,22–24]. Importantly, due to the strong coordination bond in the precursor and in-situ confined carbonization of organic component around the metal ions, the active components are always produced as nanocrystals and intimately coupled with conductive carbon, which not only expose enormous active sites but also favor for rapid electron transfer and mechanical stability during electrochemical process [25,26]. Huang et al. reported 2D FeO x /graphitic carbon nanosheets by the catalytic carbonization of metal-agarose framework, which realized ultrahigh capacity and stable cyclic performance over 1200 cycles [20]. Despite the great advantages of IOPs-based strategies, there still remain inadequacies and challenges for 2D carbon complexes: i) thickness manipulation has rarely been reported, due to the strong chemical bonds in the third dimension of non-layered materials and/or the lack of driving force for 2D anisotropic growth. Since size plays critical role on the electrochemical properties of electrode materials [27,28], fabricating 2D carbon complexes with tailored thickness is highly desired. ii) The tendency of “face-to-face” stack of nanosheets inevitably decreases the electrochemically active sites, thus damaging cyclic stability. iii) Low throughput restricts the large-scale application. Therefore, it is of crucial significance to develop a powerful, high-yield IOPs-based strategy to produce 2D carbon complexes with controllable thickness and stable structure. Chewing gum consisting of sticky gumminess and resin is a worldwide popular sugar food. It could be blown into bubbles with hollow interior by introducing air inside, of which the walls could be regarded as 2D sheets, accompanied by obvious volume expansion. Notably, the chewing gum are more like organic gel with high viscosity, and the thickness of the bubble wall highly depends on the amount of introduced gas. Chemically, metal–organic gel could be readily obtained via a facile sol–gel process. Accordingly, we can reasonably assume that if metal–organic gel with adequate viscosity is synthesized, and gaseous products with adjustable amount can be generated inside the gel during pyrolysis process, a conditioned “blowing” process may occurs accompanied by in-situ carbonization, thus obtaining 2D carbon complexes with controllable sizes and microstructures. Herein, inspired by blowing chewing gum into bubbles, we develop a scalable, high-yield “tailored gel expanding” (TGE) strategy, successfully achieving thickness control of non-layered 2D carbon complexes. Viscous metal-polymeric gel is synthesized via a sol–gel process and subsequently applied with rapid annealing, during which vast gases release and huge volume expansion is observed. Adequate crosslinking degree of gel and controlled pyrolysis (i.e., annealing temperature and ramping rate) play critical roles on blowing the gel into ultrathin 2D sheets. Moreover, the key feature of TGE strategy for thickness manipulation is introducing NH4NO3 in the sol–gel process, which completely decomposes into gases under high temperature and thus regulates the expansion behavior of gel. Using this approach, we synthesized a series of non-layered 2D carbon complexes with the thickness ranging from 12 nm to ~1 μm, including 2D NiCo/N,O-doped carbon (NOC), (NiCo)S2/NOC, (NiCo)Se2/NOC, NiCo2O4/NOC, and (NiCo)(PO3)2/NOC. Importantly, plenty of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) branches in-situ grow on the 2D structures, impeding the restack of sheets and promoting rapid electron transfer. In addition, this strategy can be easily scaled up and the 2D products are with no impurity, omitting wasteful and tedious purification process. To explore the effect of sheet thickness on electrochemical properties, seven kinds of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC with different thickness are thoroughly characterized as anodes for lithium-ion batteries. Owing to the unique physicochemical properties of 2D structure, strong coupling interaction between carbon and (NiCo)S2 nanoparticles, and in-situ grown CNTs, these 2D electrodes all demonstrate stable lithium storage properties. Among them, the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 with thinnest thickness of 13 nm manifests best capabilities, superior cyclic performance, and enhanced pseudocapacitive behavior, which should be mainly attributed to the ultrathin thickness and adequate amount of CNTs branches. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials preparation Preparation of 2D NiCo/NOC: All of the chemical reagents were directly used as received without further purification. In a typical synthesis, 6.5 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 13.1 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, and a certain amount of NH4NO3 were dissolved in 25 mL of deionized water to form solution A, while 41.5 g of citric acid was dissolved in 48 mL of ethylene glycol to form homogeneous solution B. Solution B was then added to solution A under vigorous stirring, and the pH value of the mixed solution was adjusted to 9 by adding NH3·H2O. Afterwards, the homogeneous suspension was heated at 80 °C for 4 h and subsequently at 120 °C for 6 h. The resulting gel was quickly transferred to a tube furnace at a temperature of 750 °C for 1 h under N2 atmosphere. Finally, the 2D NiCo/NOC product with fluffy structure and large volume expansion was obtained after cooling down to room temperature. For the synthesis of 2D NiCo/NOC-0, 2D NiCo/NOC-1, 2D NiCo/NOC-2, 2D NiCo/NOC-3, 2D NiCo/NOC-4, 2D NiCo/NOC-5, and 2D NiCo/NOC-6, the amounts of NH4NO3 were 0 g, 0.54 g, 1.08 g, 1.62 g, 2.16 g, 2.7 g, and 4.32 g, respectively, and corresponding molar ratios of NH4NO3 to metal ions were 0:10, 1:10, 2:10, 3:10, 4:10, 5:10, and 8:10. Preparation of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC: The as-prepared 2D NiCo/NOC and S powder with mass ratio of 1:1 were grinded evenly and then heated at 450 °C in N2 for 2 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C min−1. After cooling down to room temperature, the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC product was obtained. Preparation of 2D (NiCo)Se2/NOC: The as-prepared 2D NiCo/NOC and Se powder with mass ratio of 1:2 were grinded evenly and then heated at 500 °C in N2 for 2 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C min−1. After cooling down to room temperature, the 2D (NiCo)Se2/NOC product was obtained. Preparation of 2D NiCo2O4/NOC: The as-prepared 2D NiCo/NOC was heated at 300 °C in air for 2 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C min−1. After cooling down to room temperature, the 2D NiCo2O4/NOC product was obtained. Preparation of 2D (NiCo)(PO3)2/NOC: The as-prepared 2D NiCo/NOC and NaH2PO2 with mass ratio of 1:20 were placed at two separate positions of a porcelain boat, where NaH2PO2 was at the upstream side. Then, the porcelain boat was heated at 350 °C in N2 for 2 h with a ramping rate of 15 °C min−1. After cooling down to room temperature, the 2D (NiCo)(PO3)2/NOC product was obtained. 2.2 Characterization The morphology and microstructure of the samples were collected by scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Sirion 200 FEI Netherlands), atomic force microscopy (AFM, Shimadzu), and transmission electron microscope (TEM; FEI Tecnai G2 F20). The crystal structure of the samples was examined by a DX-2700 X-ray diffraction (XRD) with Cu Kα radiation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on a Thermo ESCALAB 250XI) with Al Kα radiation as the X-ray source. Infrared spectroscopy was obtained by Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FT-IR, Nicolet5700). Raman spectra were collected with a Renishaw Invia Raman microscope. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA, STA449C-QMS403C) was performed with a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured on an ASAP 2020 system (Micromeritics USA) at 77 K. The specific surface area was calculated by using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model and the pore size distribution was analyzed by non-linear density functional theory (NLDFT). 2.3 Electrochemical measurement Li storage tests were carried out at room temperature based on a coin-type (CR2025) half-cell configuration. The working electrode was prepared by mixing 70 wt% 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC, 20 wt% acetylene black, and 10 wt% polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). Then, the resulting slurry was coated on a copper foil and dried at 110 °C for 24 h. The mass loading of the active material for each electrode is about 1.0–1.2 mg cm−2. The coin cells were assembled in an argon-filled glove box with lithium foil as the counter electrode, Celgard 2300 as the separator, and 1 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC)/dimethyl carbonate (DMC)/ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC) (1:1:1 by volume) as the electrolyte. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement was carried out on a CHI660E electrochemical workstation (Chen hua Instruments Co. Ltd., Shanghai) in a voltage range of 0.01–3 V. Galvanostatic charge/discharge tests were performed on a LAND test system. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was recorded over a frequency range from 10 mHz to 100 kHz with a 10 mV amplification voltage. The cathode was prepared by mixing 80 wt% LiCoO2, 10 wt% acetylene black, and 10 wt% PVDF in NMP. Then, the slurry was spread onto an Al foil and dried at 110 °C for 24 h under vacuum. The electrolyte and separator were the same as those in the half-cells described above. Electrochemical analysis of the full cell was carried out in the voltage range between 1.0 V and 4.0 V. The mass ratio of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC anode to LiCoO2 cathode was chosen as 1: 4 for the charge balance, that is, the mass loadings are ~1.1 mg cm−2 for the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC anode and ~4.4 mg cm−2 for the LiCoO2 cathode. The excess capacity of anode could ensure the sufficient utilization of cathode material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of 2D NiCo/NOC materials Firstly, we mass-produced a series of 2D NiCo/NOC materials with controlled thicknesses. The typical synthesis procedure is schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 . In the first step, metal nitrates and NH4NO3 were dissolved in deionized water to form a transparent solution, then citric acid (CA) and ethylene glycol (EG) were added into the solution under continuous stirring. The resulting sol was then mixed with a certain amount of NH3•H2O and aged at elevated temperature to induce the formation of NiCo-polymeric gel. During this process, metal cations were adsorbed onto CA molecules through the complexation with –COOH groups in CA [29]. Meanwhile, the CA crosslinked with EG via esterification process at elevated temperature, finally resulting in the formation of viscous NiCo-polymeric gel with NH4NO3 molecules integrated within the polymer network (Fig. S1) [30]. Afterwards, rapid thermal treatment was performed on the as-synthesized gel in inert atmosphere to prepare the 2D NiCo/NOC. During this carbonization process, the NiCo-polymeric gel underwent vigorous redox reaction, at which point vast gases released, and meanwhile huge volume expansion was observed for the final annealing products (Fig. S2). By regulating the amount of NH4NO3, we successfully achieved thickness manipulation of 2D NiCo/NOC from ca. 12 nm to ca. 1 μm. It should be noted that tiny CNTs uniformly in-situ grew on the surface of 2D structures owing to the catalysis effect of NiCo nanoparticles [31,32]. In addition, in our TGE strategy, the yield 2D products were without any impurities, thus omitting wasteful and tedious purification procedures, which are commonly involved in most liquid-phase methods for synthesizing 2D materials. Moreover, this process could be easily scaled up by annealing more NiCo-polymeric gel in the furnace, as evidenced by the significant amount of final products (Fig. S3). This is highly applicable for large-scale application of 2D materials. By adding different amounts of NH4NO3 in the TGE strategy, we synthesized seven kinds of CNTs-branched 2D NiCo/NOC materials. The as-prepared products are denoted as NiCo/NOC-0, NiCo/NOC-1, NiCo/NOC-2, NiCo/NOC-3, NiCo/NOC-4, NiCo/NOC-5, NiCo/NOC-6, respectively, when the molar ratios of NH4NO3 to metal ions are 0:10, 1:10, 2:10, 3:10, 4:10, 5:10, and 8:10. As shown in Fig. 2 and S4, all the products possess distinct 2D morphology with large lateral sizes up to hundreds of micrometers. Moreover, tiny CNTs are observed on the surface of carbon sheets. This could improve the electronic conductivity and inhibit stack of 2D sheets, resulting in enhanced electrochemical kinetics and structural stability [33,34]. Specifically, without adding NH4NO3 in the preparation process, the obtained 2D NiCo/NOC-0 materials possess thinnest thickness of ~950 nm and large portion is composed of CNTs. Then the thickness of thinnest 2D NiCo/NOC-1 become to ~800 nm, when a little of NH4NO3 (molar ratio of NH4NO3 to metal ions is 1:10) is introduced in the sol–gel process. Further increasing the amount of NH4NO3 (molar ratio of NH4NO3 to metal ions from 2:10 to 5:10), it can be clearly seen that the thinnest thickness of 2D products further decrease from 450 nm for NiCo/NOC-2 to 13 nm for NiCo/NOC-5. On the other hand, the lengths of CNTs become smaller simultaneously. Magnified scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images further indicate that the NiCo/NOC-5 nanosheets are covered by abundant tiny CNTs (Fig. S5). Noted that the thickness of 2D NiCo/NOC-6 do not change too much when more NH4NO3 is added. However, the CNTs on the surface of 2D NiCo/NOC-6 are quite sparse. Hence, the thicknesses of the CNTs-branched 2D NiCo/NOC are strongly dependent on the molar ratios of NH4NO3 to metal ions, but it do not change much beyond molar ratio of 8:10 (Fig. 2 o). We then investigated the textural properties of 2D NiCo/NOC materials using N2 adsorption/desorption measurements. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms exhibit type-IV isotherms with a hysteresis loop at the mediate-to-high relative pressure and a sharp uptake at low relative pressure, suggesting the existence of both mesopores and micropores. The porous structures are further confirmed by the pore size distribution plots based on non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) model, showing wide distribution of nanopores (Fig. 3b). Such hierarchically porous structure favors rapid mass/ions transportation within the materials, thus resulting in excellent electrochemical reaction kinetics. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface areas (SSAs) and pore volumes of these 2D NiCo/NOC materials are shown in Fig. 3(c) (also in Table S1). With the increased amount of NH4NO3, these 2D materials exhibited gradually reduced SSAs for NiCo/NOC-0, NiCo/NOC-1, NiCo/NOC-2, NiCo/NOC-3, mainly due to the decreased amount of CNTs. However, the SSAs turns to rise up for 2D NiCo/NOC-4 and NiCo/NOC-5 when further increase the amount of NH4NO3, attributing to the dramatically decreased thickness of 2D nanosheets. In particular, 2D NiCo/NOC-5 shows highest SSA (253.5 m2 g−1) and pore volume (0.30 cm3 g−1) among these 2D samples. The lower SSA and pore volume of 2D NiCo/NOC-6 than those of NiCo/NOC-5 should be ascribed to quite sparse CNTs on the NiCo/NOC-6. In the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns, the peaks at ~26° should be assigned to the (002) plane of graphitic carbon, and the other three peaks at ~44°, ~51°, and ~75° are belong to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of metallic NiCo alloy (Fig. 3d and Fig. S6). Raman spectra show two remarkable peaks at around ~1350 cm−1 (D band) and ~1592 cm−1 (G band), assigning to the disordered/defect carbon and sp2-hybridized graphitic carbon, respectively (Fig. 3e) [35]. The I D/I G values are in the range of 1.0–1.2, indicating the coexistence of graphitic and disordered carbon structures. In addition, the I D/I G values are proportional to the molar ratios of NH4NO3 to metal ions, mainly due to the decreased amount of graphitic CNTs as well as the heteroatoms-doping induced by the decomposed gaseous products of NH4NO3 (i.e. N2, NO2, H2O). Taken 2D NiCo/NOC-5 as a demonstration, we further analyzed the elemental composition and bonding configuration by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Besides the basic elements of C, Ni, and Co, it was found that N and O species also appear in the 2D NiCo/NOC-5 (Fig. 3f). The high-resolution C 1s XPS spectrum are fitted into four peaks of C–C (283.1 eV), C-N (284.2 eV), CN/CO (285.1 eV), and OC–O (288.3 eV), proving the N/O doping into the samples (Fig. S7) [36,37]. Furthermore, the N 1s XPS spectrum reveals the presence of three types of nitrogen species, pyridinic N (397.9 eV), pyrrolic N (400.1 eV), and graphitic N (401.5 eV), whereas the O 1s XPS spectrum reveals the presence of –CO (530.5 eV) and C-O-C/C-OH (531.7 eV) [37,38]. The XPS results indicate that N and O are structurally integrated into the carbon matrix of 2D products, resulting in the formation of N,O-codoped 2D carbon sheets. 3.2 Mechanism for the synthesis of 2D NiCo/NOC and thickness manipulation Next, we make an attempt to disclose the mechanism of TGE strategy for synthesizing 2D NiCo/NOC with tailored thickness. As mentioned above, the NiCo-polymeric gel was obtained through a liquid-phase sol–gel process, which finally became quite viscous. When applied rapid annealing to this viscous gel, vast gas generated and liberated, accompanied with blazing and large volume expansion for the annealing products. Notably, bubble-like morphology was observed more or less for the final NiCo/NOC samples (Fig. S8). This process is quite analogous with blowing the chewing gum into bubbles, which could be regarded as being constructed by 2D structured walls. It should be noted that, high viscosity of chewing gum is crucial in successfully blowing it into bubbles with thin walls. Likewise, the polymeric gel must be equipped with adequate crosslinking degree to make certain that it could be “blown” into continuous sheets rather than irregular particles. During the sol–gel process, the crosslinking reactions indeed involve (i) the coordination between Ni2+/Co2+ and carboxyl groups in CA and (ii) the esterification reaction between CA and EG, both of which contribute to the formation of viscous NiCo-polymeric gel. To confirm this, we carried out two control experiments on the basis of 2D NiCo/NOC-5. Firstly, when Ni(NO3)2/Co(NO3)2 was replaced by NaNO3 with equal pH value and ion strength, only bulk carbon was obtained (Fig. S9). This is because that the transition metal ions (i.e. Ni2+, Co2+) with vacant electron orbits could accept lone pair electrons of O atoms in –COOH of CA, thereby crosslinking different CA molecules and driving the formation of metal-CA chelates [20]. Note that Ni2+/Co2+ contain 4 vacant electron orbits, while Na+ has none. Secondly, the as-obtained products without adding EG are bulk solid instead of 2D nanosheets (Fig. S10), indicating the important role of esterification crosslinking between CA and EG. In addition to suitable crosslinking degree, the redox between NO3 – and CA, which generate vast gas (e.g., N2, NO2, CO2) during annealing process, is also critical in our TGE strategy. When Ni(NO3)2/Co(NO3)2 were replaced with NiCl2/CoCl2, the thickness of the annealing products is much thicker than 2D NiCo/NOC-5 (Fig. S11a–c). And when metal nitrates were replaced by Ni(CH3COO)2/Co(CH3COO)2, the product is mainly composed of irregular microparticles and/or bulk agglomerates (Fig. S11d–f). The above results effectively disclose the importance of NO3 –. Moreover, the formation of sheet-like structure with branched CNTs is independent of the Ni/Co molar ratio. To confirm this point, we prepared another two control samples by adding only one kind of metal nitrate, that is, Ni(NO3)2•6H2O or Co(NO3)2•6H2O, while the amount of NH4NO3 was identical with that for 2D NiCo/NOC-5. The corresponding Ni/NOC and Co/NOC manifest typical nanosheet-like structure with the same as 2D NiCo/NOC-5 (Fig. S12). Moreover, controlled pyrolysis is also of vital importance for obtaining sheet-like products, including annealing temperature and ramping rate. On the basis of molar ratio of NH4NO3 to metal ions is 5:10, no sheets but large carbon bulks are observed in the annealing products obtained at relatively low temperatures of 500 °C and 600 °C (Fig. S13a–f). On the other hand, higher carbonization temperature of 900 °C shows negligible effect on the formation of 2D structures (Fig. S13g–i). In addition, rapid ramping rate is also critical in our strategy, which could release large amount of gaseous products in a short time and thus generate sufficient gas pressure inside the gel to ensure appropriate kinetics of physical expansion during carbonization process. To confirm this point, we performed a control experiment with a slow ramping rate of 1 °C min−1. However, the corresponding product is composed of irregular carbon bulks instead of 2D sheets (Fig. S14). Taken together, the proposed formation process of 2D NiCo/NOC materials is depicted as follows. In the first step, the viscous NiCo-polymeric gel was generated through the crosslinking reaction between CA and EG accompanied with the chelation between metal ions and CA. With the assistance of rapid annealing, vast gaseous products (e.g., H2O, CO2, N2, CH4) were yield in a short time, acting as strong expanding force to blow the viscous gel into bubbles until the walls become very thin. At the same time, these polymeric walls of bubbles converted into carbonaceous materials embedded with ultrafine NiCo nanoparticles at high temperature, and then changed into 2D structured sheets after the bubbles crushed. As for blowing the chewing gum, the thickness of the wall of the formed bubbles highly depends on the amount of introduced gas. Analogously, the thickness manipulation of the 2D NiCo/NOC sheets could be achieved by regulating the amount of gaseous products generated during the annealing process. Actually, in TGE strategy, the released gases during pyrolysis of NiCo-organic gel consist of two parts: (i) the gaseous products originate from the redox reactions between metal nitrates and CA, the amounts of which are constant for these 2D NiCo/NOC products; (ii) the gaseous products generated from the decomposition of NH4NO3, which would completely convert into N2, NO2, and H2O(g) under high temperature. In this regard, we could tailor the content of generated gas during pyrolysis process by regulating the amount of introduced NH4NO3, thus achieving the thickness manipulation of 2D NiCo/NOC materials. 3.3 Synthesis and characterization of 2D NiCo-based compounds/NOC materials Importantly, the proposed TGE strategy could also produce 2D NOC sheets decorated with various NiCo-based compounds with controllable thickness, by a facile postprocessing of 2D NiCo/NOC. Notably, the 2D morphology can be well reserved for these 2D NiCo-based compounds/NOC materials after rigid high-temperature solid-state reaction. As a proof of concept, we prepared a series of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC with different thicknesses by treating corresponding 2D NiCo/NOC with sulfur powder at 450 °C. XRD patterns verify that the NiCo nanocrystals are successfully converted to (NiCo)S2 phase (Fig. 4 a), in which the diffraction peaks are consistent with the standard peaks of cubic (NiCo)S2 (JCPDS: 89-1492). SEM images show that the as-obtained (NiCo)S2/NOC samples well inherit the 2D morphology of NiCo/NOC materials along with the preservation of CNTs (Fig. 4b–h and Fig. S15). The thickness of the obtained 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC strongly depends on the selected NiCo/NOC precursor. Thus, we could obtain 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC materials with controllable thickness ranging from ~12 nm to ~1 μm. Moreover, high-magnified SEM and TEM images of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 show that numerous (NiCo)S2 nanoparticles are uniformly integrated into the carbonaceous matrix with tight adhesion (Fig. 4i and j). This structure could ensure superior structural stability during long-term electrochemical process. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image shows well-resolved lattice fringes with a spacing of 0.28 nm, corresponding to the (200) plane of (NiCo)S2 crystals (Fig. 4k). Moreover, similar to 2D NiCo/NOC, the (NiCo)S2 crystals are surrounded with few-layered graphitic carbon with interplanar distance of 0.34 nm. The selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (inset of Fig. 4j) demonstrates the polycrystalline nature of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC. Survey XPS spectrum of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC confirms the existence of Ni, Co, C, N, O, and S elements (Fig. S16). By using a Gaussian fitting method, the high-resolution Ni 2p spectrum could be deconvoluted into one spin–orbit doublet of Ni 2p 3/2/Ni 2p 1/2 and two shake-up satellites (identified as “Sat.”), characteristic of Ni2+. The Co 2p spectrum also suggests the element Co in the samples exists as Co2+ [39,40]. The S 2p spectrum can be fitted with one main peak and one shake-up satellite peak (Sat.). The binding energies centered at 164.1 and 163.2 eV correspond to S 2p 1/2 and S 2p 3/2, respectively, consistent with the typical metal-sulfur bonds (Ni-S bond and Co-S bond) [41,42]. To confirm the generality of the TGE strategy for fabricating 2D materials, we further prepared 2D (NiCo)Se2/NOC by treating NiCo/NOC with selenium powder in N2, 2D NiCo2O4/NOC by treating NiCo/NOC in air, and 2D (NiCo)(PO3)2/NOC by treating NiCo/NOC with NaH2PO2 in N2, as evidenced by the XRD patterns (Fig. S17). Taken 2D NiCo/NOC-5 as the precursor, it could be clearly seen that the corresponding (NiCo)Se2/NOC-5, NiCo2O4/NOC-5, and (NiCo)(PO3)2–5 products all well maintain the ultrathin sheet-like morphology of 2D NiCo/NOC-5 without structural degradation (Fig. 4l, o, r). Plenty of nanocrystals are uniformly anchored on the carbon nanosheets (Fig. 4m, p, s), which are branched with tiny CNTs. HRTEM images show that these nanocrystals are tightly wrapped by few-layered graphitic carbon, similar to the 2D NiCo/NOC (Fig. 4n, q, t). SEM and TEM results demonstrate the robust structural integrity of these 2D samples as well as the strong adhesion force between carbonaceous matrix and nanocrystals, which are very favorable for long-term structural stability and rapid ions/electrons transfer during electrochemical process. Furthermore, Raman and XPS analysis were used to confirm the elemental composition and valence states of these 2D NiCo-based compound/NOC samples (Figs. S18–S21). Taken together, it can be concluded that via a simple post-calcination of 2D NiCo/NOC, we acquired various 2D NiCo-based compounds/NOC hybrids with controllable thickness, demonstrating great versatility of the proposed TGE strategy. In addition to 2D NiCoM/NOC, we could also utilize the ultrafine NiCo nanocrystals as catalysts to realize further growth of CNTs on the NiCo/NOC nanosheets. The 2D NiCo/NOC-5 was subjected to annealing under N2 atmosphere with a certain amount of ethanol placed upstream. After this chemical vapor deposition process, it was observed that the 2D nanosheets were covered by luxuriant CNTs with higher density (Fig. S22). 3.4 Electrochemical performance of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC The size and microstructure of 2D materials play vital roles on their energy storage and conversion applications. To investigate these effects, the lithium storage properties of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC materials with different thicknesses were systematically measured. First, we performed cyclic voltammogram (CV) experiment of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 at a scan rate of 0.2 mV s−1 to investigate the detailed charge/discharge behavior (Fig. 5 a). In the initial scan, the two cathodic peaks at 1.58 and 0.94 V correspond to the reduction of (NiCo)S2 to metallic Ni0 and Co0 as well as the formation of Li2S [43,44]. The broad peak at ca. 0.54 V should be attributed to the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film, while the anodic peak at 1.39 V is ascribed to the partial decomposition of SEI [45]. In the anodic sweep, two distinct peaks at 2.08 and 2.39 V are assigned to the regeneration of NiS2 and CoS2 [46,47]. From the second cycle onwards, the CV profiles essentially overlap, demonstrating the high lithiation/delithiation reversibility of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC electrode. The galvanostatic charge/discharge profiles of various 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC electrodes at 0.1 A g−1 are shown in Fig. 5(b) and Fig. S23. Specially, the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 delivered initial lithiation/delithiation capacities of 1130/757 mAh g−1, respectively, corresponding to an initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of ~66.9%. The initial capacity loss may result from the formation of SEI film and incomplete conversion reaction [43,48]. The ICE of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 outperforms those of other 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC samples (Fig. S24). Note that the charge/discharge profiles from the second cycle onwards overlap very well, further suggesting the high reversibility of subsequent conversion processes. Fig. 5(c) compares the charge/discharge profiles of various 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC in the eighth cycle, demonstrating that these 2D electrodes manifest similar lithiation/delithiation behaviors. Particularly, the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 electrode manifests highest reversible capacities as well as smallest polarization. Specifically, the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 shows reduced polarization of ~100 mV, 140 mV, 160 mV, 200 mV, 70 mV, and 30 mV in comparison with (NiCo)S2/NOC-0, (NiCo)S2/NOC-1, (NiCo)S2/NOC-2, (NiCo)S2/NOC-3, (NiCo)S2/NOC-4, and (NiCo)S2/NOC-6. Moreover, the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 also delivers higher specific capacities than other samples at different densities (Fig. 5d). Specifically, the average specific capacities of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 are 787, 744, 696, 632, 563, and 540 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 0.8, 1.6, and 2 A g−1, respectively. Moreover, a high reversible capacity of 842 mA h g−1 could be recovered when the current density is returned to 0.1 A g−1. In contrast, 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-0, (NiCo)S2/NOC-1, (NiCo)S2/NOC-2, (NiCo)S2/NOC-3, (NiCo)S2/NOC-4, and (NiCo)S2/NOC-6 only deliver inferior capacities of 423, 353, 369, 200, 481, and 509 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1, respectively. The superior rate capability, smaller polarization, and higher ICE of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 should be attributed to its ultrathin 2D structure and branched CNTs, which render larger active surface, shortened ions diffusion path, as well as faster electrochemical reaction kinetics. Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) analysis confirm that 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 possess smallest charge transfer resistance than others (Fig. S25). We further conducted kinetic analysis to investigate the pseudocapacitive contribution for these 2D electrodes. As shown in Fig. 5(e) and Fig. S26–S31, the CV profiles display similar shapes with increasing scan rates from 0.2 to 2.0 mV s−1. The contribution from capacitive effect could be qualitatively analyzed according to the relationship between peak current (i) and scan rate (v): i = av b, where a and b are constants [35,49]. The b value could be extracted from the slope of log(i) against log(ν) plot. It approaches 0.5 for diffusion-controlled process, while close to 1.0 for surface-dominated capacitive behavior. The b values of these 2D electrodes are all between 0.5 and 1, demonstrating the coexistence of capacitive contribution and diffusion-controlled contribution for Li+ storage. Notably, the highest b value (0.82) of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 suggests more favored capacitive kinetics (Fig. 5f), which contributes to higher rate capability and smaller polarization of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 electrode. Furthermore, we quantitatively differentiated the capacitive contribution by distinguishing the current response i into capacitive and diffusion-controlled reactions (see detailed equations in Note S1). A dominant capacitive contribution of 82.5 % is identified for the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 electrode at 1.0 mV s−1 (Fig. 5g). As the scan rate increases, the capacitive contribution increases gradually as expected (Fig. 5h and Fig. S26-S31). It can be clearly seen that the capacitive contribution for 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 electrode is much higher than those for other 2D electrodes at the same scan rate (Fig. 5i). The increased capacitive storage of (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 should be ascribed to large active surface area, shortened ions diffusion path, and rapid electrons transfer kinetics, which are closely related to its ultrathin 2D structure and conductive CNTs [35,50]. The results are well consistent with the highest b value, smallest polarization, and best rate capability of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5. Furthermore, we tested the cyclic performance of these 2D electrodes. Clearly, the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 manifest best cyclic stability, delivering a high reversible capacity of 905 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.2 A g−1 (Fig. 5j). After repeated lithiation/delithiation processes, the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 electrode still showed highly reversible charge/discharge behaviors (Fig. S32). Remarkably, a decent specific capacity of 840 mAh g−1 is also achieved for 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 even after 500 cycles at 0.5 A g−1 (Fig. 5k), which is much higher than those of other electrodes (608 mAh g−1 for 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-0, 440 mAh g−1 for 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-1, 370 mAh g−1 for 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-2, 263 mAh g−1 for 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-3, 638 mAh g−1 for 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-4, 726 mAh g−1 for 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-6). The capacity increasing is normally related to the reversible generation of electrochemically active polymeric gel-like film and gradual activation process of the electrode material [43,48]. Ex-situ TEM images demonstrate that the original (NiCo)S2 particles gradually cracked and evolved into smaller nanocrystals during charge/discharge processes (Fig. S33), which are capable of creating more active sites for Li+ uptake/extraction. And the cracked nanocrystals with much smaller size are still tightly anchored onto the carbon nanosheets, leading to gradually increased Li+/electrons transfer kinetics. As a result, the enhanced surface-induced capacitive process could offer higher capacity at the same rate [51,52]. Moreover, the pulverization of (NiCo)S2 into smaller domains increase the contact area between electrolyte and active materials, thus facilitating the further growth of polymeric gel-like film and then contributes to increased Li+ storage capacity. Note that the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-3 delivered gradually decreased capacity in the initial cycles, which should be ascribed to the mechanical degradation of electrode and continuous formation of SEI film [53,54]. More importantly, the robust and flexible 2D structure and tight adherence between active particles and carbon matrix could effectively alleviate the internal strain induced by the volume change of (NiCo)S2 and suppress the aggregation of nanocrystals, thus enhancing the structural stability of 2D(NiCo)S2/NOC electrodes. It can be seen that a stable capacity of ~498 mAh g−1 could still be retained for 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 after being cycled at 1 A g−1 up to 1000 cycles (Fig. S34). Then, we fabricated a full cell to showcase the practical feasibility of our 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC material (Fig. 6 a). As shown in Fig. 6(b), the LiCoO2 cathode delivers a reversible capacity of ~150 mAh g−1 with CE over 99.5%. Therefore, the mass ratio of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 anode to LiCoO2 cathode was chosen as 1: 4 for the charge balance, while the excess anode capacity could make sure the sufficient utilization of cathode material. Following data is tested in the voltage range of 1.0–4.0 V and calculated based on the mass of cathode. The full cell delivers an initial charge/discharge capacities of 143/123 mAh g−1 at 0.1C (1C = 160 mA g−1), corresponding to an ICE of 86.0% (Fig. 6c). Moreover, the rest charge/discharge profiles almost overlapped, indicating that the lithiation/delithiation process of the full cell is highly reversible. More importantly, a high capacity retention of ~81.9% is achieved after 120charge/discharge cycles (Fig. 6d), suggesting excellent cyclic stability. As shown in Fig. 6(e), the corresponding reversible capacities are 116.2, 103.3, 88.2, 76.1, 58.8, and 48.3 mA h g−1 at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 0.8, 1.6, and 2.0C, respectively. Finally, our 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5||LiCoO2 full cell could effectively power a light-emitting diode (LED) with a SDUT (abbreviation of Shandong University of Technology) logo (Fig. 6f). The above results undisputedly indicate that the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 in this work is promising anode material for practical application. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have demonstrated a scalable and high-yield synthetic strategy for producing non-layered 2D carbon complexes with controllable thickness and CNTs branches, based on rapid pyrolysis of metal-polymeric gel with appropriate crosslinking degree. 2D NiCo/NOC sheets with thickness ranging from 12 nm to 1 μm are obtained in large quantities and without any impurities. A series of 2D NiCo-based nanocrystals/NOC materials with tailored thickness are further prepared via in-situ sulfuration, selenylation, oxidation, and phosphorization processes of 2D NiCo/NOC. Introducing NH4NO3 in the sol–gel process is critical on the thickness manipulation of 2D products, which completely decompose into gases and thus regulate the expansion degree of metal-polymeric gel during annealing treatment. For a case study, seven kinds of 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC electrodes with different thicknesses are evaluated as anode materials for LIBs. Specifically, 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC-5 show superior lithium storage properties in view of high reversible capacity, excellent rate capability (540 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1), and stable cyclic performance (up to 1000 cycles at 1 A g−1), owing to the improved pseudocapacitive energy, enhanced electrons/ions transport, and intimate coupling interaction between carbon and (NiCo)S2. This work is expected to opens up a new avenue for large-scale synthesis of non-layered 2D materials with tailored sizes and compositions for energy and storage applications. coredata.dc:description: Non-layered two-dimensional (2D) carbon complexes manifest great potential in energy-related applications owing to their exotic electronic structures, large electrochemically active surface, and intriguing synergistic effects. However, reliable method for mass production and thickness manipulation of 2D carbon complexes remains great challenges. Here, inspired by blowing chewing gum into bubbles, a “tailored gel expanding” strategy is proposed for high-yield synthesis of non-layered 2D carbon complexes with tailored thickness from ~12 nm to ~1 μm, by controllable pyrolysis of metal-polymeric gel with adequate crosslinking degree. The key feature for thickness manipulation is introducing NH4NO3 in sol–gel process, which tailors the expansion behavior of gel precursor during subsequent pyrolysis. Various of 2D sheets with intimately coupled N,O-doped carbon (NOC) and NiCo-based (NiCo, (NiCo)S2, (NiCo)Se2, NiCo2O4, (NiCo)(PO3)2) nanocrystals are obtained on a large scale and without any impurities. Moreover, these 2D products are branched with in-situ grown CNTs on the surface, accelerating electrons transfer and preventing the nanosheets from stacking. As a demonstration, the 2D (NiCo)S2/NOC with optimized thickness manifests excellent lithium storage properties in both half and full cells. This method paves a new path for massive and controlled production of non-layered 2D materials with tailored thickness and robust structure stability for energy-related applications.
